text: I think I did for some time
but we changed to bugsnag at some point
i'm only 70% sure of what I'm saying

I’m finally moving to aws cli,

my evenings learning:

```
#!/usr/bin/env bash

ROOT_NAME=quantumjs
# Bucket name must be all lowercase, and start/end with lowecase letter or number
# $(echo...) code to work with versions of bash older than 4.0
BUCKET_NAME=test2-$(echo "$ROOT_NAME" | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]')
TABLE_NAME=LoginTrail$ROOT_NAME

# Replace with your 12-digit AWS account ID (e.g., 123456789012)
AWS_ACCOUNT=180971085012
ROLE_NAME_PREFIX=$ROOT_NAME
POOL_NAME=$ROOT_NAME
IDENTITY_POOL_NAME=$ROOT_NAME
REGION=us-west-2

# Create the bucket
aws s3 mb s3://$BUCKET_NAME/ --region $REGION
mkdir test
touch test/foo.txt
touch test/foo2.txt
touch test/foo3.txt

aws s3 cp test s3://$BUCKET_NAME --recursive

```
I’m not even sure if I had to set my AWS_ACCOUNT
more fun than using the web UI
Big fan of the CLI too, great for searching through everything fast!

I tried this:
` aws iam list-users --output table`
but get this:
```
An error occurred (AccessDenied) when calling the ListUsers operation: User: arn:aws:iam::180971085012:user/test is not authorized to perform: iam:ListUsers on resource: arn:aws:iam::180971085012:user/
```
any ideas?
Looks like an IAM rights issue; give the "test" user the rights or maybe better use a different credential for your CLI commands that had admin rights
